text:
Corlears Street, east side, from Cherry, to and including South Streets, as seen across Corlears Hook Park and eastward on South, at Jackson Streets. Shown across the background, is the East River Bridge. ( Williamsburg ).

September 11, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
484 to 476 (from right to left) Cherry Street, ad-joining and west of the N.W. corner of Corlears Street. Also shown (right) is Corlears Street, north from but not including Water, to and including Grant Streets (where it terminates). On the west side of Corlears Street appears part of Corlears Hook Park.

P. L. Sperr
March 26, 1937

(2)
The same structures as viewed eastward along Cherry Street, towards the East River. Note there the Williamsburg Bridge and its Brooklyn pedestal. The Manhattan support is obscured by the tenements to the left. On the right is Corlears Hook Park with a vacant block-front beyond. Upon this site stood the old 1-story Crane Company building.

P. L. Sperr
April 25, 1939

(3)
Same as above, Cherry Street east across Cedar Street, showing Williamsburg Bridge.

P. L. Sperr
April 7, 1940

(1)
484 to 476 (from right to left) Cherry Street, ad-joining and west of the N.W. corner of Corlears Street. April 7, 1940

Cherry Street, west from, a point between Corlears and Jackson Streets, and across the latter, showing this slum area in various stages of clearance. To the left is Corlears Hook Park and to the right are tenements that are not to come down (according to signs).

View No. 2 is at Jackson Street and westward. Note at the right margin the W. P. A. work and time shack. This stands at the N. E. corner and appears in several other views. This agency is responsible for the preparatory razing necessary for Vladeck Houses.

View No. 3 shows the clearance at the N. W. corner. This appears fenced in in View 2. The photographer is viewing northeastward to show an interior building at the rear of No. 37 Jackson Street. The six story tenements beyond, face on the south side of Monroe Street.

June 24, 1939
Views: 1-2-3

P. L. Sperr

P. L. Sperr

(1) Cherry Street, looking east across Corlears Street, showing "Odora" building in process of demolition, for east River Drive. October 7, 1939.

(2) Same, after demolition. P.L.Speer. November 8, 1939.

(1) Cherry Street, looking east across Corlears Street, showing "Odora" building in process of demolition, for east River Drive. October 7, 1939.

(2) Same, after demolition. P.L.Speer. November 8, 1939.

1-Cherry Street, looking east of Corlears Street, showing the Williamsburg Bridge.

P. L. Sperr

2-Same, showing Hecker Flour Building.

P. L. Sperr

1-Cherry Street, looking east of Corlears Street, showing the Williamsburg Bridge.

P. L. Sperr

2-Same, showing Hecker Flour Building.

P. L. Sperr

Corlears Street, south across Cherry Street to the East River, showing the Odora and the Hecker Bldgs. prior to complete demolition. These are to be removed to provide a connecting link between the section of the new East River Drive above Grand Street, and South Street. The last mentioned begins at the foot of Corlears Street and continues on the waters edge to South Ferry. Corlears Hook Park is at the right tho obstructed from view. View 2 details the razing of the Odora Bldg. View 3 is eastward from the center of the Park to show the Williamsburg Bridge in the background. Cherry St. is to the left of the Odora Bldg.

1-2: Oct. 7, 1939
3: Nov. 8, 1939

P. L. Sperr

(1) to (3)
Corlears Street, south from Cherry Street, showing demolition of buildings for the East River Drive. The Odora and Hecker Flour buildings are on the left.

P.L.Speer.

November 8, 1939.
